snippet: Vincent Zanfardino, who had an epileptic seizure while driving in 2012 that led to a deadly crash, had been repeatedly warned by his doctor not to drive, a Bronx prosecutor said.
abstract: Bronx resident Vincent Zanfardino, who had epileptic seizure while driving on New England Thruway in 2012 and crashed into another car, killing 25-year-old Alfred Reitano, is charged with second-degree manslaughter, criminally negligent homicide, and several counts of assault; had told his doctor that he did not drive and failed to mention his epilepsy when renewing his drivers license; he could face 5 to 15 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Vincent Zanfardino, who had an epileptic seizure while driving in 2012 that led to a deadly crash, had been repeatedly warned by his doctor not to drive, a Bronx prosecutor said.

headline.main: At Trial, Epilepsy and Questions of Blame in a Fatal Crash
headline.print_headline: At Trial, Epilepsy and Questions of Blame
